conclusion: Trace the path of the light beam and determine angles of incidence and refraction/reflection.
Triangle ABC is a right triangular prism with angles A=90°, B=60°, C=30°.
Light starts from D on BC, reflects off E on AC, undergoes total internal reflection at F on AB, and exits.
EG is perpendicular to AC, intersecting BC at G. D is the midpoint of CG.
In triangle ABC, angles are A=90°, B=60°, C=30°. In triangle CEG, angle CEG=90° and CGE=60°.
D is the midpoint of CG. Triangle CEG is similar to triangle CAB, so angle CGE=angle CBA=60°.
Incident ray DE reflects at E, normal to AC at E is vertical, angle of incidence i_E=60°.
Triangle DGE is equilateral, angle DEG=60°, angle of incidence i_E=60°, angle of reflection r_E=60°.
Ray EF hits AB at F, angle of incidence i_F=30°, angle of reflection r_F=30°.
Total internal reflection at F implies n≥2, but diagram shows ray exiting, suggesting refraction.
Incident angle at D is i_1=60°, angle of refraction r_1=30°, Snell's law: sin i_1=n sin r_1.
At F, Snell's law: n sin i_F=sin r_3, implies i_1=r_3, incident and emergent rays are parallel.
Angle of deviation is 0° since incident and emergent rays are parallel.
